thread.title: Classical music tunes up for fall season
thread.title_full: Classical music tunes up for fall season

author: Robert D. Thomas
title: Classical music tunes up for fall season
text:
October is kickoff month for many classical music organizations around the Southland as 2015-16 schedules move into full swing. Following are some events that caught my eye:
Organist Sheen
Rising young British organist Benjamin Sheen plays the historic David John Falconer Organ at St. James in the City. Sheen, the assistant organist at St. Thomas Church in New York City, recently captured the inaugural Longwood Gardens International Organ Competition and won second place and the Jon Laukvik Prize, the 50th year of the St. Alban’s International Organ Competition in 2013.
When: 6 p.m. Oct. 11.
Where: St. James in the City. 3903 Wilshire Blvd., Los Angeles.
Information: 213-388-3417, www.saintjamesla.org
Handel & Haydn Society
The Handel & Haydn Society, the oldest continuously performing arts organization in the United States (among other things, it gave the U.S. premiere of Handel’s “Messiah” in 1818), appears at the Valley Performing Arts Center as part of its bicentennial tour.
When: 8 p.m. Oct. 15.
Where: Valley Performing Arts Center. 18111 Nordhoff St., Northridge.
Information: 818-677-8800, www.valleyperformingartscenter.org
Organist Bull
Organist Christoph Bull journeys from his UCLA home, where he is university organist and professor of organ, across town to the First United Methodist Church as the featured organist in the Los Angeles Bach Festival. Bull’s appearance is also part of the church’s “Third at First” music series (events take place on the third Saturday of the month).
When: 9 a.m.-7 p.m. Oct. 17.
Where: First United Methodist Church, 500 E. Colorado Blvd., Pasadena.
Information: 626-796-0157, fumcpasadena.org
Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra
Music director Jeffrey Kahane leads the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra in a program that includes the Concerto for Marimba and Strings by Emmanuel Séjourné, with Wade Culbreath as soloist; Mozart’s Piano Concerto No. 18 in B-flat Major, with Richard Goode as soloist, and works by Timo Andres and Haydn.
When: 8 p.m. Oct. 17 in Glendale, 7 p.m. Oct. 18 in Los Angeles.
Where: Alex Theatre, 216 N. Brand Blvd., Glendale; Royce Hall at UCLA, 340 Royce Drive, Los Angeles.
Advertisement
Information: 213-622-7001, www.laco.org
Los Angeles Philharmonic
Music director Gustavo Dudamel leads the Los Angeles Philharmonic in a program that begins with Stravinsky’s Suites Nos. 1 and 2 for orchestra and concludes with “The Rite of Spring.” All programs, except Friday, will include the U.S. premiere of “Mysteriën” by Dutch composer Louis Andriessen.
When: 8 p.m. Oct. 15, 16 and 17, 2 p.m. Oct. 18.
Where: Walt Disney Concert Hall, 111 S. Grand Ave., Los Angeles.
Information: 323-850-2000, www.laphil.com
Peninsula Symphony
Music director Gary Berkson leads the Peninsula Symphony in the season-opening concert titled “Brahms Cycle I.” The concert will conclude with Brahms’ Symphony No. 1; each of the other three concerts will include another of the four Brahms symphonies. The first program also will include Richard Strauss’ “Serenade in E-flat Major” and the rarely heard “African Suite” by 20th century Nigerian composer Fela Sowande. All four concerts are free.
When: 7 p.m. Oct. 25.
Where: Redondo Union High School; 222 No. Pacific Coast Highway, Redondo Beach.
Information: 310-544-0320, www.pensym.org
Robert D. Thomas is a freelance music writer. He can be reached at BobTatFORE@aol.com.
